text: Merci à Marc-André pour cette visite de lAlbion! Dégustée en cask à lapéro. Liquide évidemment sans mousse, voilé et blond comme un rayon de miel. Parlant de miel, cette bière me rappelle un bol de céréales granola de marque Quaker ® dans lequel on aurait jeté une cuillère de miel. Le grain donne le ton et est agrémenté dun houblon feuillu mais timide. Celui-ci noccupe quune place bien secondaire en apparence, mais assure un important équilibre. Amertume plaisante en fin de bouche alors que je note des flaveurs qui tirent de plus en plus vers la pomme verte. Croquante, équilibrée et pleine de corps. cette bière incarne à elle seule tout ce que jattends dune bonne bitter.
On tap at Albion. Golden with a ring if foam. Aroma of wet cereals, nice bitter taste, very solid. Hight carbonation because its on tap and not on cask.

La principale chose qui me vient en tête en finissant cette pinte de la bitter, cest la douceur du liquide. Même à seulement 4%, le liquide se boit tellement facilement que cen est déconcertant. En bouche, cest toutefois assez mince, un peu floral, un peu caramélisé - cest loin dêtre désagréable, soyons-en certains, mais je mattendais peut-être à un peu plus de goût. La finition est ce qui me déçoit un peu plus, alors que cest un peu métallique, avec petite amertume bizarre.

Off white small head that disappear quite fast after couple of sips. The aroma is subtitle, hints of honey, malted cereals and field wild flowers. As for the taste, the cereals, honey are very present, the hops brings black tea flavours and it ends with a smooth bitterness.

Off white small head that disappear quite fast after couple of sips. The aroma is subtitle, hints of honey, malted cereals and field wild flowers. As for the taste, the cereals, honey are very present, the hops brings black tea flavours and it ends with a smooth bitterness.

July 19, 2015. On cask at the brewpub. 
Amber with almost no head. Aroma is cereal, grain, honey, notes of caramel and floral hops. Taste is medium sweet, malty with caramel notes, some honey, soft earthy and floral bitterness with a soft rounded finish. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. 
Very good and drinkable!

En cask à la brasserie. Une belle mousse crémeuse couronne le liquide. Pas très épaisse mais très persistante. De couleur dorée tirant sur le ambré. En bouche, les céréales dominent avec le grain avec en finale une pointe damertume légère. L effervescence est juste mais la bière est servie légèrement trop froide pour un cask. Les saveurs se présentent sous forme principalement décorce de grain, davoine ainsi quune amertume herbacée aux notes de concentré de verdure. Excellent exemple du style.

Légère déception que cette bitter pas tant quelle est mauvaise mais après la superbe mild et lincroyable blanche, la meilleure bitter (selon Ratebeer) se devait dêtre tout simplement divine. Elle est bonne mais pas à ce point.

Une bière dorée foncée avec sa mousse élégante. Son nez est fait de houblons épicés et floraux et de malts légèrement toastés avec une levure qui semble apporter un profil fruité. Les saveurs sont toutes en équilibre. Délicatesse est ici un mot clé. Il y a un petit piquant en fin de bouche. Encore une fois, le corps est impressionnant. Je mattendais à quelque chose de fantastique : je ne suis aucunement déçu davoir bu une très bonne bière.

Draft @ pub A: bready, light citrusy, light caramel app: clear copper no head t/p: thin to med body with moderate long bitter finish soft carbonation. O: superb a taste of England. Everything is in place. Sessionable no doubt.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2015 Cask at the brewpub. First time being here, I must say that the look of the place is a pretty authentic setting for an english pub. Anyway, back to the beer. Pours a clear light copper with a medium and tenacious white head (thank god for the beer engine!) that leaves some of the nicest lacing Ive ever had from a cask beer. Nose is of grass and light caramel. Pretty simple but this is intended here. Taste is of caramel as well, moderately bitter and ends on a earthy bitter finish. Body is light to medium and carbonation moderate (higher than I ever expected). Overall a really nice and properly served bitter, Id drink a lot more bitters if all were like that!

on cask on the premises - dimpled mug. almost clear very pale golden with an eternal creamy eggshell white, sticky lacing. grainy cereals, lightly spicy, wort fruitiness - not really worty but oh-so-worthy, pepper and leafy grassiness, tasty active yeasy - dusty, peppery; tea leaves and soft earthy notes. light carbonation, light body - never watery, very smooth and balanced earthy-grassy-herbal finish.. this is not a homie-rating.. this bitter is a true masterpiece.

On tap and from cask at lAlbion.
Pours amber with medium-high creamy beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma is of malt, sugar, citrus, caramel, minerals, fruits. Some esters. Taste is of malt, english hops, slight caramel, some grain. Very slight maple sap. Palate: Light body. Overall: Very refreshing. Tasty, flawless, smooth. Easily the best bitter I ever had. Balance is awesome. This is art. You cant taste anything "behind" the beer. [Cask: Also very good. The dry hop was a bit vegetal tough. Rating is for tap version]. I shall return.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2014 On cask at LAlbion (Joliette). Hazy copper/amber with a medium fully lasting creamy beige head and good lacing. Aroma is fresh cereals, earthy notes, caramel, light citrus and leafy hops. Taste is also of fresh cereals kight citrus, caramel, honey notes and bitter finish. Medium body. Low carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel. Clean finish. This beer is the epitome of drinkability. Im really impressed. This beers alone is worth the trip to Joliette. I finished my pint in 6 sips. While its so drinkable, its damn tasty too. My new favorite session beer. I wish I had access to this everyday. Wow!

Also had the tap version. The main difference are: The head is less creamy. The aroma is less hoppy (and theres not the leafy/green presence). Body it not creamy. Carbonation is medium. Finish is a little dryer. Almost as drinkable. 8-4-8-4-16 = 4.0/5

Si ça cest le meilleur exemple de bitter disponible au Québec, je veux encore plus mettre un pied lautre bord de lAtlantique. Un beau breuvage céréalier à la buvabilité extraordinaire....mais je laime un peu plus avec 1/3 de old stock.

Belle bière dorée, limpide, à peine voilée et où flotte un fin col dense laissant une large dentelle au verre.  Des arômes de pain grillé, de foin, de conifères et des notes de cuir.  Moyennement amère avec une acidité soutenue et une légère minéralité.  Bière à la texture lisse, de corps moyen, effervescence fine, elle se termine sur une amertume honnête et de légers arômes.
a true bitter ! so easy to drink its ridiculous. very respectful of the genre and on cask its heaven in a glass. bravo !

Aroma:Very light nose, malt and hops..
Appearance:Light amber,small head..
Flavor:Light grapefruit hops,candy..

Verre, à la brasserie de Joliette. Arômes de malt biscuité et de houblon herbacé et floral. Robe dorée et légèrement trouble, effervescence moelleuse et légère dentelle. En bouche, le malt se démarque par de belles notes biscuitées, légèrement grillées. Le houblon herbacé et floral est également perceptible, bien que plutôt en retenue. Leffervescence naturelle et délicate contribue à une texture en bouche moelleuse et agréable. Finale sèche présentant une fine amertume houblonnée. Une très belle bière de soif.

On tap at Albion.The colr is a clear amber with a white head and nice lace. The taste that is very distinctive of a british bitter is of hops fruits and yeast,it leaves a good taste in your mouth. The aroma also of hops and citrus fruits and some sweetness added.This was a very very good beer to have again and again.

On tap at brewpub.
Appearance : Clear amber with a small white creamy head. Small head, nice lacing.

Aroma : Herbal hops with light caramel. Lots of grain and malt. 

Taste : Herbal and floral hops, light catamel. Light bitterness on finish. Great herbal hops oin finish.

Overall : Very good but I expected a bit more seeing previous ratings. Very nice color with nice foam. Finish is delightful. Nice hops and malt overall. Very tasty for 3.9% thats for sure. I hope I get the chance to sample this again in the future.

Drank on tap (20 oz) at the brewpub, on April 2, 2011. Blonde honey, little head. Aroma hops lightly sweetened with honey, sweet barley notes. Dry hop taste with hints of herbs and raw barley, good bitterness. A verry good flagship beer!

Clearish, well settled light amber covered by a beautiful white foam which leaves superb lacing. The freshness of its aroma is stunning, bringing back memories and invoking the rare tear of beatitude. Fairly fruity yeast profile is in unisson with the lightly toasted, soft malts. What impresses the most is the extremely authentic mouthfeel, enveloping the mouth with an uncommon richness and minerality aplenty for one built out of such a small frame. Almost creamy, foamy texture yet with smallish, elegant constantly working small bubbles. Bright and fresh grain flavour extraction. An immensely refreshing drink, closing the gap with a minty and grassy smooth hoppiness. The easiest beer to drink in Quebec. I swear the second pint went by in 6 gulps.I tried a couple hundred bitters in my life and this is easily among the best. The only problem with the rest of the best ones Ive had was that many were just a straight half-pint and frequently less plus they were mostly had in intense drinking days where Id drank so many bitters that I was not in the perfect mood to hand a top score. Ill revisit UK one day and confirm this score that seems out of proportion compared to my other bitter ratings, but this beer is one of a handful that passed the test of "do I feel like drinking one every day for the following week?" If this were an imperial stout, the scores would average 4.5+.

On tap at the brewpub (about 50 oz). Quite pale colored bitter, with a generous 1 inch head in my pint. Aroma of honey, fresh grain and english yeast. Taste is grainy and sweet and finishes with a nice grassy hop bitterness. Body is full for the style but the lively carbonation and bitter finish make it an incredible session beer.

En fût. Pinte dégustée directement à la brasserie. Arôme: Légère odeur dhoublons et de céréales. Apparence: La couleur est blonde légèrement voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréales avec une pointe de citron et de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de céréales en arrière goût. (Rating #3431)

A lightly hazed golden ale with a thin lacing off white head. A nice biscuitty malt aroma with light british hops, burned caramel, berry notes. In mouth, a smooth bitter ale with light treacle, very drinkable, and super smooth. On tap at brewpub, Dec. 27 2010.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2016 My Bottom Line:
This Bitters engaging, lightly honeyed cereals, soft carbonation and talkative leafy hop bitterness provide a pint of rare authenticity.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam circles the veiled golden.
-There are very few "house blonds" of this caliber in North America. Its nice to know that a new brewpub cares as much about its staple beer as its stronger offerings. This is not dumbed down for the masses.
-This is obviously very drinkable at 4%, yet it never feels like a lighter beer. Lots of flavor and lots of drinkability.
-The mellow carbonation (on tap) properly emulates that of a cask. Nicely done. The cask version (hand-pulled) is breathtaking, with a cushiony mouthfeel and as many cereal flavors as you can imagine, all balanced by leafy, fruity hops.
-The leafy hop bitterness is quite lengthy. Makes you want to get another gulp quickly!
-The tap version is very good, but the hand-pulled cask is mindblowing. My score is for this cask experience, which happens to be more and more common now at this pub!

On tap and on cask (marvelous) at the brewpub.
